title: 105_s2207
content:
The "Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998" aims to empower the Attorney General to prevent mergers and acquisitions that could harm competition in the telecommunications industry. It amends the Clayton Act to address restraints of trade specifically related to telecommunications. The "Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998" defines a large local telephone company as one serving more than 5 percent of telephone access lines in the US. It prohibits mergers or acquisitions of such companies unless approved by the Attorney General and FCC to promote competition in telecommunications services. The Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998 defines a large local telephone company as serving over 5% of telephone access lines in the US. It prohibits mergers or acquisitions of such companies without approval from the Attorney General and FCC to enhance competition in telecommunications services. The company must have implemented requirements of the Communications Act of 1934, including regulations from the Commission and States. The Attorney General must report findings on the merger's impact on competition within 10 days to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees. The Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998 requires large local telephone companies seeking to merge to file an application with the Attorney General and FCC simultaneously. The district courts have jurisdiction to prevent such mergers or acquisitions. The Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998 mandates that large local telephone companies must file merger applications with the Attorney General and FCC concurrently. District courts have the authority to block mergers inconsistent with specified conditions. SEC. 4. PRESERVATION OF EXISTING AUTHORITIES.

This Act does not affect antitrust laws or FCC authority regarding mergers of large local exchange carriers.

SEC. 5. APPLICABILITY.

This Act applies to mergers or acquisitions of controlling interests in large local telephone companies after its enactment.
